The true answer to this question is to know your substances well, so you can easily identify a solute form a solvent. But I’m assuming you might be asking how can we differentiate a solute from a solvent. A solvent dissolves other substances, while a solute dissolves in other substances. The easiest way to tell occurs when a solid or gas dissolves in another in a liquid. The solid or the gas would be the solute and become the aqueous state, while the liquid is the solvent. If a liquid were to dissolve in another liquid, we would just say that they are miscible; i.e, they are able to mix with each other and do not form separate layers (like oil on water). If we really have to label one as the solvent and one as the solute, the solvent would be the one with the larger quantity.
